results.title: Grand Juries in D.C. Reject Wave of Charges Under Trump’s Crackdown
results.abstract: The persistent rejections suggest that the grand jurors may have had enough of prosecutors seeking harsh charges in a highly politicized environment.

multimedia.caption: Grand jurors have refused in at least seven recent cases to indict their fellow residents who became entangled in the president’s show of force.

results.title: Tensions Mount As Trump Administration Threatens Federal Crackdown in Chicago
results.abstract: In a social media post, President Trump said Chicago was “about to find out why it’s called the Department of WAR.” Illinois officials condemned the message.
results.byline: By Hamed Aleaziz and Julie Bosman

multimedia.caption: Metal barricades were placed around the federal courthouse on Thursday night in the heart of Chicago’s downtown.

results.title: ICE Has Begun Immigration Crackdown in Massachusetts
results.abstract: The operation includes Boston, whose mayor has drawn the administration’s ire for speaking out against the growing scale of its immigration actions.

multimedia.caption: A homeland security officer observed a news briefing by Mayor Michelle Wu in Boston last month, after Attorney General Pam Bondi demanded that Boston lift its sanctuary city policies.

results.title: President of Peace, Department of War. A New Name Sends Mixed Signals.
results.abstract: President Trump’s renaming of the Defense Department comes amid his campaign for a Nobel Peace Prize. On Saturday, he wrote on social media that Chicago was “about to find out why it’s called the Department of WAR.”
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: President Trump signed an executive order on Friday to change the name of the Defense Department to the Department of War. Without congressional approval, the new name will be only ceremonial.
President Trump signed an executive order on Friday to change the name of the Defense Department to the Department of War. Without congressional approval, the new name will be only ceremonial.

results.title: In India’s Rebound From Trump Blows, Modi Has No Easy Choices
results.abstract: The unraveling of relations between the United States and India has convinced many Indian officials that the country should return to its difficult balancing act of nonalignment.

results.title: At George Mason University, Trump Has Found an Unbending Adversary
results.abstract: Gregory Washington, George Mason’s first Black president, runs a university that prizes diversity. That has made him a target of the Trump administration.

multimedia.caption: The Trump administration demanded that Gregory Washington, president of George Mason University, personally apologize for supporting diversity programs. He said no.
multimedia.copyright: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times

results.title: What Has the Trump Administration Gotten From Law Firms and Universities?
results.abstract: A recent ruling against the Trump administration’s federal funding cuts was a temporary win for Harvard. But a dozen other institutions already struck deals with the government involving millions of dollars in payments and commitments to prioritize causes championed by the president.

results.title: Settlement Talks Stall Between Harvard and the Trump Administration
results.abstract: One major reason is said to be an emerging divide within the administration over whether the current framework is too favorable to Harvard.
results.byline: By Michael C. Bender, Michael S. Schmidt and Alan Blinder

multimedia.caption: The Trump administration has opened more than a dozen federal investigations into Harvard over a variety of targets, from the university’s admissions policies to its patent paperwork.
multimedia.copyright: Sophie Park for The New York Times

results.title: Thrust Into the Line of Fire, Iranians Worry About What Comes Next
results.abstract: A 12-day war in June upended the shadow war rivalry between Israel and Iran. Some Iranians want to strike back, others want to move on.
results.byline: By Declan Walsh and Nanna Heitmann

multimedia.caption: Over 12 days of war in June, more than 1,000 Iranians were killed in Israeli attacks. Most were civilians.

results.title: What’s Inside the Envelope That U.S. Open Winners Get? It’s Not a Check.

results.title: A Japanese Island Preserves an Ancient and Ghostly Theater Form
results.abstract: Noh was once the entertainment of medieval warriors. Today, remote Sado Islanders embrace one of the world’s oldest surviving types of drama.
results.byline: By Martin Fackler and Ko Sasaki

multimedia.caption: Shinobu Kamiyama, center, playing the tormented ghost of a famously beautiful woman in the play “Tamakazura” at Ushio Shrine on Sado Island, Japan. Noh dramas often center on supernatural visitations.

results.title: Bernie Sanders Stumps for Mamdani as Part of Fighting Oligarchy Tour
results.abstract: Mr. Sanders will host the Democratic front-runner for mayor of New York City at a town hall in Brooklyn on Saturday night. The two marched in a Labor Day parade that morning in Manhattan.

results.title: ‘Father Mother Sister Brother’ Takes Top Prize at Venice Film Festival
results.abstract: The film, directed by Jim Jarmusch, details three stories of three families. “The Voice of Hind Rajab,” about a Palestinian girl in a car under fire by the Israeli military, won second place.

multimedia.caption: The director Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion for Best Film for “Father Mother Sister Brother” at the 82nd Venice International Film Festival on Saturday.

results.title: Man Is Identified 52 Years After He Vanished, Bringing ‘Rest’ to His Sisters
results.abstract: Eric Singer left his Ohio home on his bicycle, never to be seen again. With the help of advances in DNA research, he was finally found.

multimedia.caption: Eric Singer was 22 when he was last seen alive in Cleveland in 1973.
